I wouldn't discourage new ideas or crossing boundaries.  JUnit is great as a standalone, complete unit test framework.  It's also useful as an assertion and test driver library.  

We use JUnit at Macromedia for plain old unit testing, but we also have a homegrown automated functional test framework that uses JUnit (via Ant) for assertion, test driver, and reporting capabilities.

Scott Stirling
JRun QA
Macromedia

Guillaume,

	I'm wondering if you could be clever and just run all the tests
on
the same machine by putting the client and the server on the same
machine
(within the same vm even). Remember that the point of JUnit is not to
functionally test the software. It is to unit test it. Try to break down
your code into small testable pieces. By testing each piece you will
have
greater control and more confidence that it will work once you put it
together. It may not even be necessary to run the client and server at
the
same time if you take this approach; the test case could act as the
server
for testing the client and vice-versa. These are just a few thoughts --
the
details of your particular program may prevent such an approach. But if
you
are testing your code from the very beginning you shouldn't have too
much
trouble doing it.

Chris

Subject: [junit] Junit support for non-standard distributed applications


Hello,

I'm working on a Java layer implementing various communication 
infrastructrure betwen processes based on raw TCP and UDP. I would 
like to test it using Junit. However, this requires me to write a 
test case which is distributed among many processes which act as 
client/servers.

I've looked into jakarta's cactus, and Junit EE but I understand they 
would support only distributed applications based on standard 
communication protocols (namely HTTP and an EJB contained)

Is there an extension to Junit that would support testing of non-
standard distributed applications?

I've started designing an RMI-based version of the junit interfaces 
where a testcase could spawn one or more "distributed test cases" 
running on remote hosts and that would report their status through 
the originating test's TestListener. I'm basically remotizing the 
junit interfaces.

I wonder if such extension would already exist and if I could reuse 
it rather than redoing this from scratch. 

Thanks for your help,

Guillaume.
